Question_1.Context: In radiopharmaceuticals, radionuclidic purity is important to ensure the safety and efficacy of the pharmaceutical.
Question_1.Question: What is the minimum radionuclidic purity of [177Lu]lutetium for radiolabeling according to the European Pharmacopoeia?
Question_1.Source: According to the European Pharmacopoeia, [177Lu] lutetium for radiolabeling must have a radionuclidic purity of greater than 99%.

Question_2.Context: The presence of radionuclidic impurities in radiopharmaceuticals is strictly regulated.
Question_2.Question: What is the allowed concentration of [177mLu]lutetium impurity in [177Lu]lutetium as per the European Pharmacopoeia?
Question_2.Source: According to the European Pharmacopoeia, [177Lu] lutetium for radiolabeling must have a radionuclidic purity of greater than 99%, whereas [177mLu]lutetium (< 0.07%) and an overall radionuclidic impurity (without [176Yb]ytterbium and [177mLu]lutetium) of < 0.01% is allowed.

Question_3.Context: Sterility is a critical quality attribute for intravenous radiopharmaceuticals to prevent infections.
Question_3.Question: What is the exemption limit for [177mLu]lutetium for the unrestricted release of solid and liquid substances?
Question_3.Source: For [177mLu]lutetium, the exemption limit is 1 × 106 Bq and 0.1 Bq/g for the unrestricted release of solid and liquid substances.

Question_4.Context: The decay of radionuclides is characterized by their half-life, which is the time required for half of the radionuclide to decay.
Question_4.Question: What is the physical half-life of [177Lu]lutetium?
Question_4.Source: [177Lu]lutetium decays to stable [177Hf]hafnium with a physical half-life of 6.64 days.

Question_5.Context: Radionuclides can decay through different pathways, emitting particles and radiation of specific energies.
Question_5.Question: What is the main gamma emission energy when [177mLu]lutetium decays to [177Lu]lutetium?
Question_5.Source: In the first case the main gamma emission is 414 keV (17.4%).

Question_6.Context: The production of radionuclides can follow different pathways, which may affect the purity and impurity profile of the final product.
Question_6.Question: What is the target material used in the non-carrier added (n.c.a) pathway for the production of [177Lu]lutetium?
Question_6.Source: The n.c.a. pathway leads via neutron irradiation of [176Yb]ytterbium to [177Yb]ytterbium, which then decays to [177Lu]lutetium by beta emission, 176Yb(n,γ)177Yb → 177Lu.

Question_7.Context: The presence of long-lived radionuclidic impurities in radiopharmaceuticals can pose challenges for waste management.
Question_7.Question: What is the physical half-life of the metastable impurity [177mLu]lutetium?
Question_7.Source: The long-lived [177mLu] lutetium decays in 22.7% of the cases to [177Lu]lutetium and in the other cases to [177Hf] hafnium (77.3%), with a physical half-life of 160.4 days.

Question_8.Context: The radionuclide [177Lu]lutetium is used in radiopharmaceuticals and can be produced through different methods, which may lead to the presence of impurities.
Question_8.Question: Which radionuclide is the first approved drug that contains [177Lu]lutetium?
Question_8.Source: The first approved drug that contains [177Lu]lutetium is Lutathera®.

Question_9.Context: The concentration of radionuclidic impurities in radiopharmaceuticals is critical for ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.
Question_9.Question: What was the average concentration of [177mLu]lutetium found in Lutathera® according to the data?
Question_9.Source: They concluded that Lutathera® has an average concentration of 311 Bq/g ± 200 Bq/g and 0.8 ppm [177mLu]lutetium.

Question_10.Context: In the context of radiopharmaceuticals, the radionuclidic impurity levels are crucial for determining the safety and regulatory compliance of the product.
Question_10.Question: What is the radionuclidic impurity level of [177mLu]lutetium in EndolucinBeta® samples?
Question_10.Source: The mean 177mLu-activity in the samples of EndolucinBeta® was 381 ± 511 Bq/g, which represents a radionuclidic impurity of < < 0.01% (approx. 0.0000037 ± 0.0000053%) which is very far below the limit of 0.01% stated on the certificate of analysis.
